choices.text: Brain dead donor who is an identical twin
Living donor who is an identical twin
Brain dead donor who has the same blood group
Living donor who has the same blood group

questions.text: Which of these is the ideal donor for organ transplant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Living donor who is an identical twin

 

Option B: A living donor who is an identical twin is the ideal choice for organ donation. This is because there would be a perfect HLA match, which is critical for reducing the risk of allograft rejection, and the organ would not have been subjected to any ischemic changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A brain-dead donor who is an identical twin would be an excellent match in terms of HLA compatibility. However, the organs may have suffered from the events leading to brain death and subsequent changes in physiology.

 

Option C. A brain-dead donor who has the same blood group can be a suitable donor, but without the genetic matching of an identical twin, there is a higher risk of rejection.

 

Option D. A living donor who has the same blood group is better than a deceased donor in terms of organ quality, but the risk of rejection would still be higher compared to an identical twin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal organ donor is a living donor who is an identical twin of the recipient due to the perfect HLA match and the optimal condition of the donated organ, which significantly reduces the risk of rejection and improves transplant outcomes.

 

  • Transplants from live donors have a number of advantages over deceased donor organs. Live donor organ from healthy individuals without the comorbidities commonly seen in deceased donors.
  • In the agonal period, before death, deceased donors exhibit marked changes in physiology related to a catecholamine storm and this can cause organ dysfunction. Clearly, live donor organs are not subjected to this insult.
  • Allograft rejection is directed against human leukocyte antigens (HLAs). These are a group of cell surface glycoprotein molecules. HLA molecules are divided into class I (A, B and C) and class II (DR, DP and DQ).
  • They are highly polymorphic, i.e., their amino acid sequences differ widely between individuals. To give an example, there are > 1000 variants of the HLA-B gene. This genetic variability means that most transplant donors and recipients have different HLA profiles. HLA profiles will be the same in identical twins, hence chance of mismatch is low.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1597-99

choices.text: Sirolimus
Tacrolimus
Azathioprine
Mycophenolate Mofetil

questions.text: A 55-year-old male has recently undergone a successful kidney transplant. To prevent graft rejection, his medical team plans to initiate maintenance immunosuppression therapy. Which of the following drugs is a mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor that is suitable for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sirolimus

 

Option A: Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor that is used in maintenance immunosuppression therapy after kidney transplantation to prevent organ rejection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor, not an mTOR inhibitor, and is used for immunosuppression in transplant patients, but it works via a different mechanism.

 

Option C. Azathioprine is an antiproliferative agent and is used as an immunosuppressant; however, it does not inhibit mTOR.

 

Option D. Mycophenolate mofetil is also an antiproliferative agent that inhibits the proliferation of T and B cells but is not an mTOR inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sirolimus is a mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor used in the maintenance phase of immunosuppression following kidney transplantation to prevent graft rejection.

 

Drugs used for immunosuppression in a patient for kidney transplant are:

 

  1. Calcineurin inhibitors
  • Cyclosporine
  • Tacrolimus

 

  1. Antiproliferative agents
  • Azathioprine
  • Mycophenolic acid

 

  1. Mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors
  • Sirolimus
  • Rapamycin
  • Everolimus

 

  • Immunosuppression for transplantation has two phases: Induction and maintenance. Induction therapy commonly consists of a combination of high-dose intravenous steroids and the anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody basiliximab, which blocks IL-2 receptors. Other induction agents for high-risk cases are ATG and the monoclonal antibody alemtuzumab.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1601-02

choices.text: The donor kidney is transplanted heterotopically into one of the iliac fossae
The transplant renal vein is anastomosed end to side to the external or common iliac vein.
The renal artery is anastomosed end to side to the external iliac artery in a deceased donor
Donor ureter is anastomosed to recipient ureter via a spatulated anastomosis

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement of the following about the technique of renal transplant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Donor ureter is anastomosed to recipient ureter via a spatulated anastomosis

 

Option D: This statement is incorrect. In renal transplant surgery, the donor ureter is typically anastomosed directly to the recipient's bladder, not to the recipient's ureter, using the Lich–Grégoir technique to create a new vesicoureteral junction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is a correct statement as the donor kidney is typically placed in a location different from the original kidneys, which is in the retroperitoneal iliac fossa.

 

Option B. This is the standard practice for the venous anastomosis in renal transplantation, making this statement correct.

 

Option C. This is also correct as the renal artery can be anastomosed to the external iliac artery via a “Carrel patch” which can be obtained in deceased donor. In living donor transplants, the donor renal artery is anastomosed to recipient internal iliac artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In renal transplantation, the donor ureter is not anastomosed to the recipient ureter but is instead anastomosed to the bladder as an extra-vesical anastomosis using the Lich–Grégoir technique.

 

Renal transplant operative technique

 

  • The donor kidney is transplanted heterotopically into one of the iliac fossa via a curvilinear incision.
  • The transplant renal vein is anastomosed end to side to the external or common iliac vein.
  • The renal artery is anastomosed either end to side to the external or common iliac artery (via Carrels aortic patch) or end to end to the divided internal iliac artery
  • The internal iliac artery is used more commonly for live donor kidneys because of the lack of an aortic patch.
  • After revascularisation of the transplant kidney the ureter is anastomosed to the bladder as an extra-vesical only (the Lich–GreÃÅgoir technique)

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1604

choices.text: Sub-Optimal Kidney Transplant
Dual Kidney Transplant
Additional Kidney Transplant
Domino Kidney Transplant

questions.text: Transplantation of a pair of marginal quality kidneys from the same donor into one recipient in order to provide adequate nephron mass is called as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dual Kidney Transplant

 

Option B: Dual kidney transplant is the correct term for transplanting two kidneys from the same donor into a single recipient, which is done to provide sufficient nephron mass, especially when the kidneys are from an expanded criteria donor or are of marginal quality.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sub-optimal kidney transplant typically refers to a transplant involving a kidney that is not in optimal condition, but can be used a bridge to formal renal transplant.

 

Option C. Additional kidney transplant is not a standard term used in transplant medicine for this scenario.

 

Option D. Domino kidney transplant refers to a specific type of transplant where an organ or tissue is transplanted from one person to another and then from that person to another recipient, which is not the case described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dual kidney transplantation is the process where two marginal quality kidneys from the same donor are transplanted into one recipient to ensure adequate nephron mass and function.

 

Dual kidney transplantation

 

  • This involves the transplantation of a pair of marginal quality kidneys from the same donor into one recipient in order to provide adequate nephron mass.
  • Both kidneys can be placed in the same iliac fossa.
  • This approach is used for kidneys from elderly Donor after Circulatory Death and so-called expanded criteria donors, which are defined by age > 60 years or age >50 years with at least two of the following: hypertension; terminal creatinine >133 μmol/L; death from stroke.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1604

choices.text: Recurrence of Disease
Renal Vein Thrombosis
Renal Artery Stenosis
Dehydration

questions.text: Which of these is not a cause of early graft dysfunction in renal transplant patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Recurrence of Disease

 

Option A: Recurrence of disease is not typically a cause of early graft dysfunction, as the recurrence of the original kidney disease in the transplanted organ generally takes time to develop and is not expected to present immediately post-transplant.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Renal vein thrombosis is a significant cause of early graft dysfunction due to the immediate impairment of blood flow it can cause in the transplanted kidney.

 

Option C: Renal artery stenosis can lead to early graft dysfunction by reducing blood flow to the transplanted kidney, causing ischemia and potentially acute renal failure.

 

Option D: Dehydration can cause pre-renal acute kidney injury by decreasing blood flow to the kidneys, leading to early graft dysfunction if severe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrence of the original disease is not a common cause of early graft dysfunction in renal transplant patients; as such recurrences typically occur later in the post-transplant course. Early graft dysfunction is more often caused by factors such as acute rejection, vascular complications, infections, or technical issues.

 

Causes of early graft dysfunction

 

Any rise in serum creatinine of >10% of baseline or ≥20 μmol/L should be considered as acute allograft dysfunction that requires investigation. Possible causes are:

 

  • Acute Rejection (Antibody Mediated or Cell Mediated)
  • Calcineurin Inhibitor Toxicity
  • Dehydration
  • Urinary Tract Infection or Pyelonephritis
  • Any other source of Sepsis
  • Renal Vein or Renal Artery Thrombosis
  • Ureteric Obstruction or Urine Leak

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1606

choices.text: Acute Rejection
Chronic Rejection
Renal Artery Stenosis
Dehydration

questions.text: A 58-year-old male who underwent a kidney transplant 7 years ago presents with gradually worsening renal function over the past year. He has no signs of infection, maintains good hydration, and reports compliance with his immunosuppressive medications. A renal biopsy reveals interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy without evidence of acute inflammatory changes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's renal dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Rejection

 

Option B: Chronic rejection, which can manifest as either chronic AMR or chronic CMR, is a significant cause of long-term graft dysfunction and is considered the most common cause of late graft failure. The biopsy findings are typical of chronic rejection

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute rejection, both antibody-mediated (AMR) and cell-mediated (CMR), can lead to early graft dysfunction (within few months).

 

Option C. Renal artery stenosis can lead to graft dysfunction due to ischemia; however, it is less common than chronic rejection and doesn’t match the biopsy.

 

Option D. Dehydration can cause acute pre-renal failure but is not a common cause of long-term graft failure in kidney transplant patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic rejection is the most common cause of graft failure/dysfunction in kidney transplant, typically presenting as progressive organ dysfunction over time due to immunological factors.

 

Causes of long-term graft dysfunction

 

Immunological

 

  • Chronic AMR (anti-body mediated rejection)
  • Acute CMR (cell mediated rejection) or AMR, which can occur at any time

 

Non-immunological:

 

  • Pre-existing damage in the donor kidney (especially relevant to DCD and extended criteria donor kidneys)
  • Early ischaemia - Reperfusion injury
  • Chronic calcineurin nephrotoxicity
  • Ureteric or bladder outflow obstruction
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis
  • BK polyomavirus nephropathy
  • Recurrent native disease: glomerulonephritis; focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; immunoglobulin A nephropathy
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Poorly controlled hypertension
  • Dyslipidaemia

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1606-1607

choices.text: Post-Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disorder (PTLD)
Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Skin
Leukemia
Kaposi’s Sarcoma

questions.text: A 63-year-old male, who received a kidney transplant 2 years ago and has been on chronic immunosuppressive therapy, presents with multiple hyperkeratotic lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin. Biopsy of one lesion confirms malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Skin

 

Option B: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is the most common malignancy seen in post-transplant patients due to chronic immunosuppression, particularly in sun-exposed areas, matching the presentation described.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PTLD refers to a range of lymphoid proliferations that can occur following transplantation due to immunosuppression. However, it does not present with hyperkeratotic skin lesions.

 

Option C. Leukemia can occur in the post-transplant setting but would not present with localized skin lesions, but with pancytopenia and splenomegaly.

 

Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma can occur in transplant patients but typically presents as violaceous plaques or nodules and is less common than squamous cell carcinoma in these patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common malignancy seen post-transplant in patients on immunosuppressive therapy is squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, often occurring on sun-exposed areas.

 

Most common malignancy seen post-transplant immunosuppressive therapy is Squamous cell carcinoma of skin

 

Complications of immunosuppression:

 

Infections:

 

1. CMV - 4 to 8 weeks Post-Transplant - Pneumonia/Retinitis/Encephalitis

Treatment - Valganciclovir

2. Pneumocystis jirovecii - Fungal Pneumonia

Malignancy: - Skin Cancers (MC- Squamous Cell Carcinoma)

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 27th Ed. Pg 1541, Box 82.5

choices.text: Living Related Donor
Living Unrelated Donor
Deceased Brain-Dead Donor
Deceased Circulatory Dead Donor

questions.text: Maastricht grading is used to categorize?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Deceased Circulatory Dead Donor

 

Option D: The modified Maastricht classification is widely used to categorise DCD (Donation after Circulatory Death).

 

 

Controlled grades of donors (III/IV) are more suitable.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1596

choices.text: Severe Acute Pancreatitis with Sepsis
Malignant Melanoma
Prion Disease
Primary CNS Tumor

questions.text: A 46-year-old male with a history of a brain lesion treated with surgical resection and no evidence of metastasis is evaluated for kidney transplantation. Which of the following conditions in the patient's history is not considered an absolute contraindication to transplant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary CNS Tumor

 

Option D: A primary CNS tumor, especially if it is a non-metastatic lesion that has been treated, is not an absolute contraindication to organ transplantation. This is an exception to the rule against transplanting in the setting of malignancy due to the low risk of metastasis outside the CNS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Severe acute pancreatitis with sepsis is typically a contraindication, until the sepsis is under control. Active systemic sepsis at the time of transplant would be an absolute contraindication.

 

Option B. Melanoma is an absolute contraindication to transplant. Non-melanotic skin tumors are not.

 

Option C. Prion disease, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, is an absolute contraindication to organ transplantation due to the high risk of transmitting the disease through transplanted tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary CNS tumors, particularly those that are localized and have been treated without evidence of metastasis, are not considered an absolute contraindication to organ transplantation. This is in contrast to systemic malignancies and certain untreatable or high-risk infections.

 

Contraindication to organ transplant:

 

Absolute

 

  • Creutzfeldt Jacobson Disease (Prion Disease)
  • Active Systemic Sepsis
  • Malignancy in previous 5 years (except Primary CNS tumour, Non-Melanotic Skin Ca and CIS of uterus)

 

Relative

 

  • As a further response to the organ donor shortage, organs are now being transplanted from donors with meningitis/encephalitis, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis B and C and high-risk behaviour with the potential for blood-borne infection

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1596-97

choices.text: Metabolic Alkalosis
Chemical Cystitis
Reflux Pancreatitis
Prostatic Abscess

questions.text: A 25-year-old type 1 diabetic with ESRD underwent simultaneous pancreatic-kidney transplant (SPK). Which of these is not a complication of bladder drainage of transplanted pancreas?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic Alkalosis.

 

Explanation:

 

If transplanted pancreas is drained into bladder instead of small bowel, there is loss of bicarbonates from the pancreatic secretions, leading to metabolic acidosis.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1627

choices.text: Hepatic Artery
Portal Vein
Bile Duct
IVC

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with Child C Cirrhosis and Hepatitis C is undergoing a liver transplant. Which anatomical structure should the surgeon prepare to anastomose first in the recipient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. IVC

 

Explanation:

 

Option D: The IVC, both supra-hepatic and infra-hepatic, is usually the first part to be anastomosed during liver transplantation to establish venous outflow from the liver, which is critical to providing immediate blood drainage from the graft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first structure to be anastomosed in the recipient of a liver transplant is the IVC, specifically starting with the supra-hepatic IVC, followed by the infra-hepatic IVC, to establish adequate venous outflow from the liver.

 

Order of anastomosis in recipient of liver transplant is:

 

  1. Supra-hepatic IVC
  2. Infra-hepatic IVC
  3. Portal Vein
  4. Hepatic Artery
  5. Bile duct

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1610-1611

choices.text: Skin
Gastrointestinal tract
Liver
Lung

questions.text: In a patient with graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) following a hematopoietic stem cell transplant, which organ is least likely to affect by this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung

 

Option D: The lung is considered the least affected organ in GVHD compared to the skin, liver, and gastrointestinal tract, although it can be involved in chronic and late-stage presentations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The skin is commonly affected in GVHD, presenting with rashes and can progress to desquamation.

 

Option B. The gastrointestinal tract is frequently involved in GVHD, which can manifest as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option C. The liver can be affected in GVHD, leading to elevated liver enzymes, jaundice, and cholestasis.

 

Educational objective:

 

While any organ can be affected by graft-versus-host disease, the lung is typically the least affected organ compared to the skin, liver, and gastrointestinal tract, which are more commonly involved in acute presentations of the disease.

 

  • Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) occurs due to the presence of immunocompetent T lymphocytes in the graft attacking the immunodeficient recipient tissue due to histocompatibility differences within 100 days, causing tissue damage.
  • Organ most affected by GVHD - Skin
  • Organ least affected by GVHD - Lung
  • Any organ can be affected in GVH reaction. The most important is the involvement of immune system, skin, liver and intestines.

 

Ref: Online reference – Bailey and Love 27th Ed. Pg 1537.

choices.text: Most common indication in a child is biliary atresia
Liver transplant may be done in liver malignancies
In auxiliary liver transplant, native liver is left in situ
Liver is resistant to acute rejection

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about liver transplant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liver is resistant to acute rejection

 

Option D: This statement is incorrect. The liver, like any transplanted organ, is susceptible to acute rejection. Although the liver may have a higher tolerance for immunologic insult compared to other solid organs, acute rejection can occur in all organs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Biliary atresia is indeed the most common indication for liver transplantation in children, making this statement correct.

 

Option B. Liver transplantation is an established treatment for selected patients with Hepato-Cellular Carcinoma (HCC) and fulfills specific criteria such as the Milan or UCSF criteria.

 

Option C. In auxiliary liver transplantation, part of the native liver is left in place, and a portion of a donor liver is implanted. This procedure may be considered for certain indications, making this statement correct.

 

Educational objective:

 

The liver is not resistant to acute rejection; it is susceptible to acute rejection like any other transplanted organ, and acute cellular rejection is a common cause of graft dysfunction early after liver transplantation.

 

  • In adults the most common causes are alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), chronic viral hepatitis (hepatitis B virus [HBV] and hepatitis C virus [HCV]). In the last two decades hepatitis-related CLD (HBV and HCV) was the most common indication for LT.
  • In children, who account for around 10‚Äì15% of all LTs, biliary atresia is the most common indication for transplantation.
  • LTx is indicated as a curative treatment for selected patients with HCC, haemangioendothelioma and hepatoblastoma.
  • Milan criteria (one lesion ‚â§5 cm, or three or fewer lesions ‚â§3 cm each)
  • UCSF criteria (one lesion ‚â§6.5 cm, or three or fewer lesions ‚â§4.5 cm each, with a total tumour diameter ‚â§8 cm)
  • Auxiliary LT involves implanting a healthy liver graft placed either heterotopically or orthotopically while leaving all or part of the native liver intact. Auxiliary heterotopic LT, where the graft is implanted below the native liver, was proposed as an alternative to orthotopic LT.
  • Liver graft dysfunction can happen any time after transplantation; if not identified early and treated promptly, it can lead to graft loss. The most common presentation is an asymptomatic elevation of liver enzyme levels. Early after LT, acute cellular rejection is the most common cause of graft dysfunction and is usually treated by increasing the dose of immunosuppression.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1608, 1610, 1614, 1618.

choices.text: Hyperacute Rejection occurs due to T Cell Mediated Destruction
Acute Rejection occurs during first 6 Months
Chronic Rejection is the most common cause of Graft Failure
Chronic Rejection is characterized by Myo-Intimal Proliferation on Biopsy

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about graft rejection:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperacute Rejection occurs due to T Cell Mediated Destruction

 

Option A:

 

  • This statement is incorrect. Hyperacute rejection is not primarily mediated by T cells. It is an immediate and severe form of rejection that occurs due to pre-existing antibodies against the graft, typically antibodies against ABO or human leukocyte antigens (HLA). These antibodies lead to rapid complement activation and destruction of the transplanted organ.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B.

 

  • This statement is generally accurate. Acute rejection is most common in the early post-transplant period, and it often occurs within the first few months after transplantation. However, acute rejection can occur at any time post-transplant.

 

Option C.

 

  • This statement is correct. Chronic rejection can contribute to graft failure over time. Graft failure can result from various factors, including acute rejection, infections, vascular complications, and other non-immunological factors.

 

Option D.

 

  • This statement is generally accurate. Chronic rejection is associated with long-term changes, including fibrosis and myo-intimal proliferation in the blood vessels of the transplanted organ. This can be observed on biopsy as a characteristic feature of chronic rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of Graft Rejection

 

  • Hyperacute rejection
    • Immediate graft destruction due to ABO or preformed anti-HLA antibodies
    • Characterised by intravascular thrombosis and interstitial haemorrhage
       
  • Acute rejection
    • Usually occurs during first 6 months
    • T-cell dependent
    • May be cell mediated, antibody mediated or both
    • Usually reversible
       
  • Chronic rejection
    • Occurs after first 6 months
    • Most common cause of graft failure
    • Antibodies play an important role
    • Noe-immune factors contribute to pathogenesis
    • Characterised by myointimal proliferation in graft arteries leading to ischaemia and fibrosis

 

Ref: Bailey 27th Ed. PG 1535.
